I had no idea that the number of these people in Australia would increase under a Labour Government. A fair question to ask is, Why has there been this increase under the Labour Government? The honorable member for Perth has suggested that we might make more comfortable the immigrants who come here from the Old Country, but they have not the harsh conditions to which those who emigrate to the United States of America and to Canada are subjected. These are crowded together on the Atlantic steamers, and herded together in trains for journeys of 3,000 or 4,000 miles. I cannot understand why, in view of what we can offer, more people do not come to Australia. In 1910 our increase of population, excluding aboriginals, was only 143,624, and when I was in Canada the immigrants numbered over 40,000 a month. We cannot hold this country without population, and if we do not treat the matter seriously our children will be worked in harness by Asiatic invaders as the Chinese employed on the construction of the Pine Creek railway were. We have no hope of holding "this country unless the question of filling it up is taken seriously. People with special knowledge acquired in other countries should be encouraged to come here to help us to develop our vacant spaces. We shall never be able to develop the Northern Territory with the knowledge gained in the south. Our imports are increasing, and our exports are decreasing. I would stop that kind of thing by giving bonuses for the production of commodities which we are not at present putting upon the market.
- Would the honorable member increase the Tariff?

- I am not suggesting anything of the kind, but we should attract to Australia people who are specialists, and who would be able to open up new industries. It is a remarkable fact that the population of the Northern Territory has decreased during the last twelve months. In 1910 there were 3,301 people there; in 191 1 there were 3,248. There was also an increase in the coloured population of the whole Commonwealth. Still more extraordinary is it that there has been a decrease in the population of Tasmania.
- Since the growth of the Labour party there.

- There is no country on earth where people have better opportunities than Australia. We are not doing enough to attract population from parts of Europe where the people lead a hard and often miserable existence. In Western Australia, between Albany and the Leeuwin, there is room for a million people. At present there are not enough there to cultivate 20,000 acres. That is the sort of place where we should settle good workers. The climate is temperate, and industrious folks could earn a competency there. I have recently been through Canada, and am satisfied that there is no comparison between that country and this. In Italy and the south of France you can see people carrying soil up the hill-sides in baskets and putting it on the hill-tops, where they cultivate. Surely it would not require much inducement to persuade them to come to the Commonwealth, where there are splendid opportunities for industrious agriculturists.
- What would they grow under such conditions?

- Everything that is grown in Italy and the South of France can be produced here, and of the finest quality. I saw tons of olives being grown in Italy, but I never saw an olive tree there that grew as well as the olive trees in Australia. Yet the amount of labour which these Europeans have to devote to induce their trees to produce is enormous. Why cannot the advantages of Australia be pointed out to these people? I am sure that if honorable members opposite could see men toiling as -I have seen them toiling in Italy for a mere pittance, it would appeal to them as it appealed to me. They cannot realize the facilities afforded them in Australia, and do not know that with much less labour they could earn a comfortable living, and put by something for old age. If the actual facts regarding this country were supplied to them, they would be attracted in thousands.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: . - The speech which the honorable member for Fremantle has just made displays a condition of innocence with regard to the Labour party on the subject of immigration that surprises me. He has spoken at length about the need of population in Australia, and the opportunities which we have lost of bringing people from other parts of the world where there is a superabundance of population. The honorable member seems- to have missed the true solution of the anomaly, that people are anxious to come to Australia from various parts of the world, and are not afforded a chance. The anomaly is that the Labour party are speaking with two voices everywhere and all the time. The honorable member has been reading a portion of the report of the High Commissioner, in which he speaks at great length of the expenditure which he is controlling with regard to the advertising of Australia. He seems to imagine that because people are not coming here, therefore this advertising is doing no good. The honorable member appears to have entirely missed the fact that, whilst on the one hand we are expending money in England, holding out specious and exaggerated promises with regard to what people can get in Australia, on the other hand the trade unions and the Labour party, with their organization, are sending home cables and letters giving the lie to the very advertisements for which the people of Australia -are paying. We are familiar with scores of Occasions on which these Labour organizations have told the world that there is no raced for population here. I read this morning from the Federal Labour manifesto a few extracts showing that the Labour party, as a whole, treat this question of immigration, not from a philanthropic or national point of view, but purely from an economic point of view, being afraid of their lives that every fresh person who comes into this country is going to take the' bread out of their mouths. Therefore, it pays them to stand upon the public platform, when they are amongst their own constituents, or those whom they hope to make their constituents, ana tell them plainly that there is no room in Australia for the people for whom we are advertising in England -

quote.para: That the trades unions of New South Wales, as represented by Congress, request the State Government to discontinue its immigration policy.

speech.para: That resolution goes to Great Britain by the same mail that carries the advertising literature. Is it not natural that people in England, who hear these two voices - one a political voice, which seeks to beguile them with the idea that they ate wanted, and the other an economic voice practically threatening them with starvation if they come - are bewildered, and that the best efforts of the Government and the High Commissioner are stultified ? At the same Labour Congress, a resolution was passed asking the State Government to at once take steps to stop the " indiscriminate system of immigration " now obtaining, and to bring out only competent persons for whom it could be proved there is legitimate employment without displacing local and competent labour, and that a deputation representing the Congress and the Labour Council executive wait on the Government without delay. The people brought out to Australia are not imbued with the socialistic and revolutionary opinions entertained by a large section of the Labour organizations of this country ; and it is known that honest working men from the Old Country are likely to take the places vacated owing to senseless strikes, thus interfering with the hole-and-corner monopoly now obtaining in Australian industries. The honorable member for Fremantle, in a rather unsophisticated way, expressed some surprise that people are not coming here more numerously; but to me the explanation is self-evident. If from my door I invite people to come in and get something, and a moment afterwards tell them that there is nothing for them, the only effect must be to cause some amusement without affecting my purpose one way or the other. The attitude of the Trades Union Congres is at least frank and incapable of misconstruction ; it is bitterly opposed to immigration, and one speaker declared that the policy of the Labour Government was " criminal," from the point of view of the working classes. This economic consideration lies at the root of a great many wild and senseless doctrines that have been promulgated by the Labour party and Labour members individually.

We are devoting £600,000 to Commonwealth buildings in London, with the object, primarily, of directing the attention of the working classes to the immense attractions of Australia, and we expend £16,000 a year on a stafF in England whose business it is to induce people to come to this country; but, at the same time, letters and cables are being sent, behind our backs, to the trades organizations at Home in order to give the lie to the representation of our immigration officials. The High Commissioner, in his report, tells us that, with the funds at his disposal, it is impracticable to undertake a vigorous and business-like campaign for the purpose of advertising our food products; and at the end of the report are some very interesting illustrations of the steps he has been able to take in this direction. According to these pictures, one of the means adopted is a cinematograph car, which is taken about the country in order to show people generally what wonderful harvests and crops are reaped in this country. To my mind, all this represents the biggest piece of humbug and hypocrisy that could possibly be carried on by a great country like Australia. Canada, though she spends much money in advertising, does not resort to such means of making the advantages of the Dominion known. And I undertake to say that in Canada there is no great body of people corresponding with the Labour party of this country, who are endeavouring to render abortive the expenditure that is ostensibly in the interests of patriotism. The more this political fraud is made known the better. It is only, as it were, by accident that we learn through the press what sort of resolutions are being passed at Labour congresses, and what opinions are expressed by Labour members on the platform and, hypocritically, in this House. But we who do know of this double work, should not hesitate to expose one. of the most consummate pieces of humbug that could be connected with the policy of n great country. Canada spends hundreds of thousands a year in advertising her great resources ; and, although the Dominion " cannot hold a candle " to Australia for fertility, equability of climate, and general attractions, she is receiving thousands of people while we are obtaining only a few. That is because there is no second voice in Canada to tell the English people that they may fmd a fool's paradise on their arrival.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from S.jo to 10 a.m. (Friday).

talk.start.para: . - I desire this morning to adduce some further evidence in support of the view that members of the Labour party at present in power,- even if they were sincere themselves in desiring immigration - which, as to a good many of them, I venture to express some doubt - are paralyzed in any efforts they may make by the undoubted hostility of the great mass of their supporters to any active policy of the kind.
- Do not the honorable member's supporters influence him in airs way ?
- They do.
- Then, is it wrong that our supporters should influence us?

- I am not questioning the morality or immorality of influence of the kind ; all I am endeavouring; to maintain is that, assuming that some, or even all, of the gentlemen who now occupy the Government benches were quite willing to advocate a rational policy of discriminative immigration, they are, in fact, paralyzed by the real opinion of the majority of their supporters outside..
- That applies with equal force to the honorable member himself and his supporters.

- The policy of the Labour party has been, not to encourage, but to impose fetters on, immigration. In the report prepared by the Agents-General in 1905, at the request of the then Prime Minister, we are told by gentlemen, be it remembered, who were engaged in the actual work of immigration and of advertising the resources of Australia in the various Dominions -

quote.para: As pointed out by us in our report upon " Advertising the Resources and Development of the Commonwealth," the language test and contract provisions of the Act referred to have proved veritable stumbling blocks to us in our work, and have had a most prejudicial influence on the public opinion of every part of this Kingdom.

Lest we should be misunderstood, we would like to emphasize the fact that we are strongly -in sympathy with the desire of our fellow Australians to preserve Australia for the white races, and to maintain a high standard of living and of wages ; but we should be very blind,, indeed, if we were not aware that of the many causes that have tended to prejudice Austra'ia in the estimation of the public, none has had an influence so 'widespread and striking as the cases which have arisen under the contract provisions of the Immigration Restriction Act. lt is true that persons who have ill-will towards Australia have grossly exaggerated the cases to which we refer, but however arising, the fact that these cases have happened has led the press and business men to a close examination of the Act, and to the discovery of the sweeping range of the language test, and of the severe nature of the penalties imposed. The press of this country has not been slow to point out that if a mechanic or an agricultural labourer goes to Australia under contract to perform manual labour, he becomes liable to six months' imprisonment, and that the wording of the contract clause has a tendency so wide as to appear even to include domestic servants of all kinds.

speech.para: I have no doubt that the Act does include domestic servants of all kinds -

quote.para: We have endeavoured to defend the position of the Commonwealth on the grounds that the provisions objected to are for emergent use, and that common-sense is the prevailing characteristic of the Australian people j but our explanations pass unheeded amidst the recurrent clamour which arises whenever the six hatters are mentioned- Nor have we found that it assists matters overmuch to refer to the legislation of other countries. The section of the Act itself is taken as typical of the real attitude of Australia towards the question of immigration. The title and wording of the Act and the reports of the cases that have occurred, exaggerated as they have been by repetition, are deeply impressed upon the minds of the great bulk of the people. Even the more thoughtful elements of the community who are aware of the genesis of the language test, and accept it as a more or less illogical compromise made at the instance of the Imperial Government - strongly resent the contract provisions. They cannot understand why four millions of British people living 13,000 miles away from the Motherland, and admittedly suffering from a lack of population, should exclude the occassional British artisan or labourer against whom the section is aimed. They argue that it is absurd to think that immigrants under contract ever would or could be landed in such numbers as to affect the labour market of any State. On the contrary, they consider that the insistence by such immigrants on a contract which guarantees them against want of employment is a commendable precaution which the labour market should, welcome rather than condemn.

speech.para: These are the matured statements of the only people who at that time, in 1905, had had practical experience in the work of immigration, and they were made for the information of the Prime Minister of the clay. I venture to say that no truer thing was ever said than that the section of the Act providing that any immigrant, no matter how otherwise desirable as an Australian citizen - no matter how qualified to help in developing this country, or what his character may be, physically, mentally, and morally - shall not be entitled to come here under any contract that secures to him proper employment the moment he lands is taken as typical of the real attitude of Australia towards immigration ; and it is as true now as it was in 1905. The ostensible reason why that section was passed in the form in which it now stands was apparently to prevent employers flooding the country in times of strike with employes brought out here under contract. I do not believe that there was ever a danger of such a thing. Moreover, I do not believe that that was the real reason. I think that honorable members opposite and their supporters know perfectly well that there is no danger of such a thing.

talk.start.para: - Our experience teaches us of the cruelty that is practised under such a system.

- I venture to say that the honorable member is not able to point to a single instance in which if that provision had not been inserted men would have been brought out here under contract to stop a strike.
- I have seen five or six cases of the greatest cruelty.
-- If the honorable member ventures to reply to what I am saying - and I have grave doubt as to his doing so - I hope that he will tell us of these cases.
- He could easily reply.
- Then honorable members cannot object to our arguments if they remain dumb.
- We are here to do business, not to make advertising speeches.

- Then the honorable member says that if he were to tell us of these cases of hardship he would be making an advertising speech. I do not believe that any cases of hardship or cruelty have been prevented by this contract section. We cannot have any system of immigration that will be successful as long as we fetter it with conditions under which people are invited to leave the surroundings of a lifetime, and to venture upon a new life 16,000 miles away without any guarantee that they will be able to get employment the moment they land here. To allow this "provision to remain is, as the Agents- General declared in 1905, a most distinct declaration of antipathy to any real policy of immigration on the part of the party which now occupies the Treasury benches.
- Would the honorable member allow men to come out under a contract of any kind?

- The honorable member's inquiry, like all coming from the same source, is a trap question. Most certainly I would not support absolute liberty of contract free from any restriction. What I have said throughout is that the Government support an absolute prohibition. Their party caused this section to be placed in the Act, and have since persistently refused to allow any modification of it.
- Since when?
- Since it was first embodied in the Act of 1901.
- The Act of 1901 has been amended.
- But this general prohibition has never been modified.
- Yes, by the Act of 1905.
- I think it will be found that there is nothing in the Act of 1905 that is inconsistent, with the general view I have expressed.

- Under the Act of 1905 It is provided that any one coming from Great Britain under contract must be permitted to enter if the contract provides for the payment of rates of wages current in Australia. Under such circumstances, they can come in as a. matter of right. That provision applies only to persons coming in under contract from Great Britain.

- The honorable member has referred me to certain provisions of the Contract Immigrants Act of 1905. Section 2 contains this definition - " Contract immigrant " means an immigrant to Australia under a contract or agreement to perform manual labour in Australia (in this Act referred to as "the contract").

speech.para: Section 4 provides -

quote.para: Every contract immigrant, unless otherwise prohibited by law, may land in the Commonwealth if the contract is in writing, and is made by, or on behalf of, some person named in the contract and resident in Australia, and its terms are approved by the Minister.

speech.para: Then section 5 . provides that the Minister shall approve the terms of the contract only -

item.para: When a copy is filed with him, and, if he so requires, is verified by oath; and
If in his opinion -

item.label: (a)
item.para: the contract is not made in contemplation of or with a view of affecting an industrial dispute, and

item.label: (b)
item.para: there is difficulty in the employer's obtaining within the Commonwealth a worker of at least equal skill and ability (but this paragraph does not apply where the contract immigrant is a British subject, either born in the United Kingdom, or descended from a British subject there born) ; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: the remuneration and other terms and conditions of employment are as advantageous to the contract immigrant as those current for workers of the same class at the place where the contract is to be performed ; and
If, where the approval is sought after the contract is made, the contract contains a copy of this, and the immediately preceding section and is expressed to be made subject thereto; and
Before the contract immigrant has landed in the Commonwealth.

speech.para: I understood the Minister of External Affairs to say that the Act of 1905 provided that persons had a right to come here under contract from Great Britain if the contract provided for the rates of wages current in Australia.

talk.start.para: - If it provided for the recognition of Australian conditions.

- This Act provides nothing of the kind. It gives no right to a contract immigrant to come unless the terms of the contract are approved by the person who happens to be for the time being administering the Act. The conditions I have read are merely limitations upon the Ministerial power to permit people to come here, so that he was absolutely wrong in his statement that, under the Act of 1905, every person coming here under contract from Great Britain has a right to land.
- Then the honorable member says that contract immigrants from Great Britain cannot come here as a matter of right?
- No ; they can only come here subject to the restricted permission of the man who happens to be Minister of External Affairs at the time.

- We are not quibbling, and I should be glad of the honorable member's advice. Does he say that if a man comes here from Great Britain under contract to work at current rates of wages, I can " turn him down? "

- Legally, the Minister could do so. The law says so. It is a matter -of plain English requiring no legal opinion. Two conditions are imposed. First of all, the contract must be in writing, and, secondly, the Minister must approve of it. Has the Department taken any different view?
- Yes, on legal advice.
- I have never heard the honorable member for Flinders, as a lawyer, speak before in this House until he had considered the question with which he had to deal.
- The policy I have named is that laid down under legal advice that we could not do otherwise. If the honorable member thinks differently, I shall inquire into the matter.

- It is not my function to advise the . Committee legally, but if the Minister can assure me that he has submitted the exact position that we are now discussing, or that it was submitted to a legal opinion-
- Yes, the exact question.
- I suppose it is in writing?
- Yes.
- Is there any objection to our seeing it?
- I was not Minister of Trade and Customs at the time.
- The Minister of Trade and Customs has said " yes " to the honorable member's question. I have not. I will look up the papers.
- Could there be anything clearer than the plain language that -

speech.para: Every contract immigrant, unless otherwise prohibited by law, may land in the Commonwealth if the contract is in writing, and is made by or on behalf of some person named in the contract, and resident in Australia, and its terms are approved by the Minister.

If the Minister had not assured me that he had a legal opinion to the direct contrary, then, with all respect to the honorable member for Gippsland, who has chosen to assume, for the purposes of debate, that I am giving an opinion that is not my own, I should have said that the language of the Act was perfectly plain.

talk.start.para: - I said that the honorable member was giving an opinion without having considered the question.
- I should have thought that the honorable member, who is also a lawyer, would take the same view as I do of this plain English.
- In view of the honorable member's opinion, I shall look into the matter.
- The Act does not say that the Minister shall approve of the terms of the contract under certain conditions, but only where certain conditions are implied. It restricts his liberty.
- There must be certain conditions. We provide for the observance of union rates of wages or the award of an Arbitration Court.
- Then the Minister says that those are the only conditions affecting his right?
- I am informed that that is so, so far as contract immigrants from Great Britain are concerned.
- I should like to see that opinion, and since it is a question of vital importance, there is no reason for the Department to observe any secrecy in regard to any legal opinion given to it.
- Not at all. The policy I have stated is that which I have followed all along, because I have been told that it is the law.
- That is another question. If the Minister has in his Department a legal opinion to that effect, the immense importance of this subject would warrant the Committee being placed in possession of it.
- I shall be very glad--

- Then we shall . have it. The provision as to remuneration undoubtedly applies to contract immigrants from Great Britain. It is true that the law says that the Minister shall not consent to a contract unless the remuneration to be paid; under it is equal to the rates of wages paid out here; but it does not say that he " shall " consent if the remuneration is equal. The Minister has assured me that he has a legal opinion dealing with this point.
- No; the Minister of Trade and Customs said that there is such an opinion. I did not, but I think there is.
- If the Minister has a legal opinion upon this matter I shall be extremely glad if he will be good enough to let us see it.

speech.para: Mr. JOSEPH COOK (Parramatta> [10.31 a.m.]. - I think that we ought to have a quorum,. [Quorum formed.] It seems to me that common-sense comes in here as well as law. If, as the honorable member for Flinders contends, the Contract Immigrants Act provides that notwithstanding that all the terms of a contract may be otherwise perfect, the Minister shall have a right of veto, that is precisely what it ought to provide. There are other reasons quite apart from' the terms of the contract which ought to give the Minister the right to intervene and to prevent an immigrant from landing here.

talk.start.para: - The Minister has promised to lay the legal opinion bearing on this matter - if he has one - upon the table of the House.

- Yes. The construction put upon the Statute by the Minister evidently is that so long as the terms of a contract as between employer and employe are unexceptional, he is under an obligation to allow the latter to enter the Commonwealth. I say that there may be a. thousand reasons - other than those which relate to the conditions agreed upon between, employer and employe - why an immigrant should not be permitted to land in Australia. Consequently there must be some residuary power in the Minister to prohibit from coming here a person who ought not to come, quite apart from the terms of an economic contract. But if the at be strictly administered as it stands, at is almost impossible for a contract immigrant to enter Australia. The Minister permits the admission of contract immigrants only by winking at a breach of the law. For instance, the Act sets out that before he may approve the terms of a contract he must satisfy himself that it is not made " in contemplation of or with a view of affecting an industrial dispute." How can he know that? Obviously he can only form an opinion. He cannot possess any knowledge on the subject. I notice that the Minister is whizzing himself out of the chamber as usual, and consequently I think we ought to have a quorum present. [Quorum formed.] The Minister before approving any contract is also required to satisfy himself, where the immigrant is other than a British subject, that there is difficulty in the employer obtaining within the Commonwealth a. worker of at least equal skill and ability. Another point upon which he has to satisfy himself is that -

item.label: (c)
item.para: the remuneration, and other terms and conditions of employment, are as advantageous to the contract immigrant as those current for workers of the same class at the place where the contract is to be performed ; and
if, where the approval is sought after the contract is made, the contract contains a copy of this and the immediately preceding section, and is expressed to be made subject thereto; and

before the contract immigrant has landed in the Commonwealth. 1 say frankly that I would not come here under contract under such conditions. How does an immigrant know that while he is on the water something has not occurred to vitiate his contract ? We ask a man to burn his boats on the other side of the world in the expectation that he will not be able to return there for many years, and to come to Australia only to find that while he was on the voyage his contract has been vitiated and disapproved by the Minister. If men come here under those conditions great must be their confidence in the Minister who may preside over this Department from time to time. I am glad that at last we are beginning to organize our ' Immigration Branch on a well defined basis, and on an adequate scale so far as machinery is concerned. I entirely approve of the proposal to erect Commonwealth offices in London. They will be a magnificent advertisement for Australia, and the expenditure will be a useful one. My only objection to that scheme is that it creates an anomaly for which the Government are responsible, inasmuch as while we are borrowing money with which to erect these London offices, we are constructing huge undertakings in Australia out of revenue. I cannot see why we should distinguish between the erection of buildings in London and the erection of buildings in Australia. In the one case the work is being paid for out of loan funds, and in the other case out of revenue. It seems to me that the Government are " sneaking in " a loan policy - that they are not doing it in an. entirely straightforward way. Whilst the present Ministry are affirming how enormously 'the stream of immigration has increased since they have been charged with the administration of the Immigration Department, another party outside is. conducting a propaganda of an entirely different character.

talk.start.para: - I think that we ought to have a quorum present.[ Quorum formed.]
- There is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.] There is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.]

- I wish to ask you, sir, whether it is not the practice of the House of Commons when . a quorum has been formed to prevent another call being made for a quorum immediately afterwards, seeing that the Chairman of Committees or Mr. Speaker, as the case may be, has already satisfied himself that there is a quorum within the precincts?
- Under our Standing Orders any honorable member has a right to call for a quorum at any time.

- While the Minister is claiming credit for having done everything that can be done to attract immigrants to Australia, another propaganda is being conducted outside with a totally different object in view. In this connexion

speech.para: I propose to read a letter which was sent to London by the Secretary of the Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners, in regard to the subject . of immigration. The letter was addressed from the Trades Hall, Goulburn-street, Sydney, and reads : -

Through the medium of your valuable columns I have been directed to place a few facts before the English public with reference to the cost of living and house rent problem in New South Wales. It would be well for intending emigrants from the United Kingdom to study these facts before attempting to emigrate to this State.
House rents during the past five years, where they were formerly gs., us., and 13s., have now risen to 17s. 6d., and as high as 27s. 6d. People are glad to get houses even at that price.
Second. - Cost of living during the last three years. The cost of living- has risen fully 301 per cent.
I hope the Government are taking full credit for that. They are taking credit for everything else.

Tradesmen in England receiving 7s. per day are better off than the men in Australia receiving ns. As you no doubt know, there are several large ventures projected, such as the Naval College and the Federal Capital, but these will not be started for years. The labour market at the present time is over-stocked - that is, as far as carpenters and joiners are concerned, a considerable number of whom are out of employment.

That letter is signed by William James Corbitt, who subscribes himself " Secretary, Sydney District Management Committee, Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners, Trades Hall, Goulburn-street, Sydney." Here is proof of a statement which has been made in the debate by the honorable member for Parkes, that the Ministerial party have spoken with two contradictory voices on this question of immigration. While Ministers themselves are claiming credit for the accession of immigrants to our shores, their party outside are taking every means in their power to prevent immigrants from coming.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member hold us responsible for that letter?
- I say that it represents the honorable member's attitude outside this House.
- Does the honorable member hold himself responsible for all the statements which the jokers in his party make outside - Walpole's statements, for instance ?
- Writing with reference to ' the letter I have quoted, the

speech.para: London correspondent of the Sydney Morning Herald says -

quote.para: The Australian trade unions have entered into a campaign of falsity in order to discourage the emigration of skilled tradesmen from this country.

speech.para: A little while ago a Trade Union Congress met in Sydney, and turned down immigration with a vengeance. The meeting was presided over by the honorable member for Cook, and the' following resolution was moved : -

quote.para: That the trade unions of New South Wales as represented by congress request the State Government to discontinue its immigration policy.

speech.para: Mr. George Saunders, milk and ice carters, submitted the following amendment : -

quote.para: That the Government be asked to at once take steps to stop the indiscriminate system of immigration now obtaining, and only bring such competent persons, for whom it can be proved there is legitimate employment, without displacing local and competent employes, and that a deputation of three from the congress as deputies, and three from the Labour Council Executive wait upon the Government without delay in reference to this matter.

speech.para: Mr. Schrieber, in supporting the amendment, made these remarks -

quote.para: That in the country the population was one and a half persons to the square mile, while in England it was 517 persons. He considered a> home should be made for Englishmen; and to carry the motion would be to make the congress the laughing-stock of all trades unionists and the country.

speech.para: Another speaker said that he considered -

quote.para: There was plenty of work in the country, for any man who wanted it. He had been thirty-two years in the State and had never been out of work, except when he took a holiday. He considered that many men were out of work because they would not accept any other employment than that to which they were accustomed. Those men were content to loaf on others.

speech.para: A show of hands showed 20 against the amendment, and a division had the same result. The original motion was then carried by 20 votes to 13. Here we have this Government taking all the credit imaginable for what they are doing to assist immigration, and striking a note of triumph as they quote figures which show the tremendous accession of people to our shores since they came into the possession of office. But while that is so, their party outside are passing resolutions affirming that an immigration policy is a huge mistake, and should be discontinued at the earliest possible moment.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member can be satisfied as to which section of the party will prevail.

- The section outside will prevail. It appears to me to be quite an understood thing. Honorable members opposite, who have to secure votes to get in here, are allowed to dictate a propaganda which will enable them to appeal to votes outside the trades unions, and for that purpose they announce, with their tongues in their cheeks, that they are in favour of immigration ; whilst the unions upon which they also depend take effective steps to prevent it. The sooner we have the facts of the case put before the public, and show what the protestations of Ministers mean, the better it will be for the promotion of immigration. I trust, therefore, that some time during this long sitting to which we have been condemned by the Caucus we shall be able to allow these gentlemen to demonstrate the sincerity of their convictions. We shall expect to see them ranging themselves in solid phalanx with honorable members on this side who are sincerely anxious to bring as many of the right sort of people to these shores as our exigencies at the moment demand. I trust that we shall soon see the organization in London strengthened in every possible way. ' Any proposals for that purpose will meet with a very generous response from this side of the House. Something will have to be done upon a very much broader scale than has yet been attempted. I am afraid that we shall not, to the extent that we desire, get men to go into the Northern Territory from the rural districts of Australia. It may be that we shall be able to induce people from over-sea to go to the Northern Territory. I trust that we shall succeed in persuading men who are already in the warmer zones of Australia to cross over. But we shall have to offer them every inducement. They will not go willingly. We shall have to fix in our minds the price that we ought to pay to induce them to settle in the Northern Territory. We can only do that by a "balancing of climate and other disadvantages with the economic and other advantages which we are able to place at their disposal. But we shall have to look to other places, apart from Australia, and apart from England and Scotland, for people to occupy the Northern Territory. For this reason we shall need to strengthen our immigration agencies as at present conducted and centralized in London. I am glad to see, therefore, an item in the Estimates for this purpose. I shall be glad to see other efforts made to widen and extend Immigration facilities in England. The more we can strengthen them and make them adequate, the better it will be for this country.

. - I think that the position of the present Government in connexion with immigration should be restated in relation to the High Commissioner's Office. An express provision of the Constitution lays upon this Parliament the responsibility of legislating for immigration to Australia.
- I think there should be a quorum to listen to the honorable member's argument. [Quorum formed.]

- In 1909 the first step of a substantial character was taken towards carrying out the provision of the Constitution to which I have alluded. In 1901 our Immigration Restriction Act was passed to deal with one phase of the matter. In 1909 the High Commissioner was appointed, and one of the most important of his duties was to advertise Australia and supervise immigration. In 1911, at the Imperial Conference, attended by the Prime Minister and the Minister of External Affairs, emigration from England was exhaustively discussed. Mr. John Burns, the President of the Board of Trade, stated that the Imperial Government was most desirous to co-operate with the various Governments of the Dominions in order that the surplus population of Great Britain might be distributed amongst the British Possessions over-seas in as equitable a manner as possible. Mr. Burns then estimated that 300,000 immigrants from Great Britain per annum could be spared. It was estimated that perhaps 80,000 of these would emigrate to foreign countries, leaving 220.000 per annum available for the Dominions. The Prime Minister consented to co-operate with the Imperial Immigration Committee-., in order that the 220,000 per annum might be distributed amongst the Dominions in accordance with their needs and requirements. The High Commissioner has prepared a report full of practical suggestions. He points out how immigration might be more successful in many directions, and indicates the need for the Commonwealth Parliament to provide ships to bring immigrants to this country. We have it on the authority of the Minister of External Affairs that a most important recommendation by the High Commissioner has been definitely rejected by the Government. The High Commissioner's office and the advertising of Australia in the Old Country cost the Commonwealth about £40,000 a year, and a further expenditure of £600,000 or £700,000 has been authorized for the election of offices in London, which it is thought will prove of immense value, commercially and otherwise, to this country. How far, under the circumstances, the Government can justify the continuance of the present expenditure and the contemplated expenditure, remains to be seen. The High Commissioner, in his report, says -

quote.para: I have had interviews with deputations of passenger agents and the heads of the shipping companies - who are both deeply interested, the former in earning commission, and the latter in promoting traffic - and I am bound, after the most careful and earnest consideration, to state that I am convinced some assurance, given by those in authority, that emigration to Australia will be encouraged and assisted for a period of at least four or five years, is needed by the shipping companies before they will build the number of passenger steamers necessary. It must be remembered that cargo steamers cannot be converted into passenger steamers, either temporarily or permanently, without a very large outlay. The modern requirements now wisely insisted upon cause ship-building for passengers to be a vastly more expensive task than it used to be.

speech.para: In this connexion the following extract from Hansard is interesting : -

talk.start.para: - Has the Cabinet given any consideration to this proposal?
- I have.
- Has the Minister come to any decision ?
- I have.
- Is the honorable gentleman going to adopt the suggestion which Sir George Reid makes?
- No.

speech.para: No reason is given by the Government for the decision at which they have arrived ; and the only possible inference is that they are under the control of the unions outside, who do not believe in immigration. Thus the members of the Ministry are tied hand and foot, whatever their own personal opinions may be. As to contract immigrants, the Minister of External Affairs has authority to approve or disapprove of any agreements submitted to him, but we know, as a matter of fact, that the control is largely in the hands of the unions, who have to be consulted, before any action is taken. When I was in Sydney, not long ago, I ascertained that an important union, which charges an entrance premium of £40 per head, had definitely refused permission to a manufacturer there to import skilled! tradesmen, and the result was that orders had to be refused, thus making way for larger importations from abroad.

talk.start.para: - I beg to call attention to the fact that there is no quorum present. - [Quorum formed.]

-The Pacific Cable Board is also referred to in the report of the High Commissioner. It is always good business to complete an undertaking once it is entered upon, and it is highly desirable that there should be an Atlantic cable to place Australia in direct communication with Great Britain. At present there is a; deficit of something like £34,000 a year on the Government cable, and I think not only that this could be wiped out altogether, but that a handsome profit could be made by the Commonwealth, if, in addition to> our control over the land-lines of Australia,, the cable to Vancouver, and, for a term, the land-line across Canada, we had control over an Atlantic cable, which, in my opinion, could be constructed for £500,000. At present the Government cable does not carry more than 10 or 15 per cent, of the total business, but, with complete communication, we should get as much business as the cable could carry. The deficit of- £34,000 is just about twice as much as would pay the interest on the cost of constructing an Atlantic cable; and such an undertaking would, in my opinion, yield! a handsome profit. The Imperial Conference of 1.91 1 decided that if the cable rates were not reduced sufficiently, it would be advisable to open up negotiations with the various Governments interested, with a view to the laying down of an Atlantic cables but, with the exception of the reference in? the High Commissioner's report, we have no information, from the Government or elsewhere, on the subject. It is of little use having these periodical conferences if the Government are not prepared to consider, and, if necessary, to act upon, the recommendations made.
- Does the honorable member contend that the resolutions or recommendations of the Imperial Conference must bind the Government ?

- No, but when a recommendation is one that would confer great advantage on the people of Australia, it ought certainly to be taken in hand by the Government ; and an Atlantic cable is a. business transaction that can be fully justified in every possible way. The High Commissioner recommends the appointment of a. commercial expert for the purpose of bringing the producers of Australia into closer touch with the British markets, which represent an immense held as yet but little exploited. I put before the Committee last night figures showing that we have open to the producers of Australia a market equal to £200,000,000 per annum. Great Britain every year imports over _£200,000,000 worth of goods consisting mostly of foodstuffs, and not more than 10 or 12 per cent, of th'at amount represents imports from Australia. This great market is open to us, and, according to the High Commissioner, there are also in most European countries markets awaiting the entrance of Australian produce. Investigations have been made in France, Prussia, Germany, and Switzerland, where, the High Commissioner informs us, there are markets for Australian produce, and there can be no doubt that there are markets waiting to be developed by us in other countries. The supervision of our produce in London requires to be conducted by a man, not of limited experience, but of the widest commercial knowledge, who could bring our producers into touch with the retailers oversea, and so arrange matters that the produce of the farmers of Australia might be placed on the tables of the consumers of the Old World at the least possible expense and a minimum amount of employment charges.
- The honorable member's time has expired.

.As I wish to address a few questions to Ministers I think it would be well at the outset to ask for a quorum. [Quorum formed.] There appears to me to be no more important item in the division now before us than that relating to the High Commissioner's Office. The matters coming under its direct supervision are all important to the Commonwealth, and too much attention cannot be paid to them.
- I direct your attention, Mr. Chairman, to the want of a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

- I think I may fairly congratulate the Government on the fact that, in view of the importance of these Estimates, they have been able to keep a House continuously for such a length of time. There can be no doubt that Australia with its territory of 3,000,000 square miles, and its population of little more than 4.500,000, is altogether under-populated, and it should be the function of the High

speech.para: Commissioner's Office to assist to bring about a better condition of affairs in this regard.

talk.start.para: - I should like a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

- I regret that my speech is being interrupted in this manner. With a population so small and an area so large it is obvious that if the avowed policy of the Government in favour of a White Australia is to be realized, there must be a. large influx of immigrants.
- There is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.]
- I rise to a point of order. I asked your opinion at an earlier hour, Mr. Chairman, as to whether it is necessary that the bells should be rung on every occasion when a request is made for a quorum.
- I rise to point out that there is not a quorum present, so that a point of order cannot be raised. [Quorum formed.]

- I was proceeding to point out that if the desire of the Government is to effectively carry out its avowed policy of a White Australia, it is essentially necessary that there should, be a large influx of people to the Commonwealth.
- There is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.]

- The High Commissioner, in a most valuable report presented to this Parliament on 19th October, 191 1, strongly urged the Government to recognise that certain action should be taken with a view of bringing more people to our shores. I appreciate the wisdom of the suggestions, and the language in wtiich the report is couched. In a further report, dated 31st March last. Sir George Reid states that -

quote.para: The satisfaction which the marked increase in the number of emigrants from Great Britain to Australia has caused has been qualified by the increasing anxiety I have felt owing to the block from which the movement is suffering at its most important point -

talk.start.para: - It is a pity that the honorable member's valuable speech should be delivered in the absence of a quorum. I ask for a quorum.
- The Government are reducing proceedings to a farce.
- You have done that for the last forty-eight hours.
- Why should members be compelled to listen to a clown ? [Quorum formed.]
- I rise to a point of order. During the ringing of the bells for a quorum, Mr. Chairman, the honorable member for Brisbane called the honorable member for Echuca a clown.
- He did not.
- I have no control when there is not a quorum present.
- Indeed you have, Mr. Chairman. You control us to the extent of refusing to allow any honorable member to lea.ve the chamber while the bells are ringing.

- I should like the expression to which I have referred to be withdrawn. I submit that when the bells are ringing for a quorum no member has a right to call another an offensive epithet, which he would not be in order in applying to an honorable member when there was a quorum present.
- Do I understand, Mr. Chairman, that you suggest that you have no control over the Committee while the bells are ringing for a quorum?
- Have you given your ruling, Mr. Chairman?
- I have not. If the honorable member for Brisbane used an offensive term towards another honorable member, I am sure he will withdraw it.
- I submit respectfully that as I did not use the word in the sense in which I was understood to use it by the honorable member for Wentworth, I cannot withdraw it.
- The honorable member for Wentworth must accept the assurance of the honorable member for Brisbane.
- The High Commissioner points out a series of hindrances in connexion with our immigration policy.
- This is a very important question, and as I know that the honorable member can deal with it in an intelligent way, I think we should have a quorum present. [Quorum formed.]

- The High Commissioner in his report points out the serious difficulty which has arisen in regard to immigration to Australia by reason of the impossibility of securing the necessary shipping accommodation. The unfortunate feature of this matter is that we have been told by one Minister that the Government have practically turned down the High missioner's report.
- It is a pity that this contribution by the honorable member should be lost. Therefore, I think we ought to have a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

- I rise to a point of order. I wish to point out that on the last two or three occasions on which your attention has been drawn to the lack of a quorum, honorable members have filed into the Chamber - in one instance they were led by the Minister of External Affairs - and have then filed out of it.
- That statement as to the Minister is not correct.

- On the last occasion that a quorum was called for the Minister of External Affairs was at the head of the. body of incoming members. Had not an. independent like the honorable member for Gippsland better rid himself of this bitter party feeling?
- It is the fact that an independent member condemns the honorable member which hurts him so much.

- - My point of order is that the Committee is not properly constituted until honorable members who enter the Chamber to make up a quorum have taken their seats. I submit that it is not in order for them to file into the Chamber and, without taking their seats, to file out through another door into the Queen's Hall. By the time they have made their perambulation attention is again called to the lack of a quorum. Such conduct is reducing our proceedings to a farce.
- I merely rise to say that the honorable member for Parramatta has made an unfair and untruthful charge against the Minister of' External Affairs.
- I require that insulting observation to be withdrawn.
- The honorable member for Brisbane is not in order in referring to any statement of another honorable member as "untruthful."

- I withdraw the term "untruthful." The facts of the case are that when the bells commenced to ring the Minister of External Affairs was on his way into the Chamber, and by a mere accident happened to be at the head of the body of honorable members who entered the Chamber to make up a quorum. I regret - that the honorable member for Parramattashould descend to incorrect statements.

- By way of a personal explanation, I wish to say that if I have done the Minister of External Affairs an injustice, I am willing to make all the reparation in my power. But I would point out that he did enter this chamber at the head of a body of honorable members. If he was not in command of them, I may be excused for having made an error, inasmuch as only a few minutes before I had seen him sitting amongst them in the Queen's Hall.
- In support of the contention of the honorable member for Parramatta, I would direct your attention, sir, to section 39 of the Constitution, which provides -

quote.para: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, the presence of at least one-third of the whole number of the members of the House of Representatives shall be necessary to constitute a meeting of the House for the exercise of its powers.

speech.para: There it is laid down that for the transaction of public business, at least one- third of the members of this Chamber must be present. My next point is that standing order 54 reads -

quote.para: Every member of the House, when he comes into the chamber, shall take his place, and shall not, at any time, stand in any of the passages or gangways.

speech.para: Reading that standing order in conjunction with the section of the Constitution which I have quoted, it is obvious that until honorable members who enter the chamber to make up a quorum have actually taken their seats, the Committee is not properly constituted.

talk.start.para: - Every honorable member is supposed to take his seat on entering the chamber, and the Committee is not properly constituted unless that has been done. I may add that it is distinctly disorderly for honorable members to enter the chamber in the form of a procession, and to pass out of it again without having taken their seats.

- When I was interrupted I was attempting to show that the High Commissioner has pointed out the extreme difficulty which is being experienced in securing the necessary shipping accommodation for emigrants from the Old Country.
- It is a pity that this oratorical effort should be wasted, and I must again call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]
- We have been told on the authority of the Minister of External Affairs -
- As the honorable member is warming to his work. I would point out that there is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.]

- It is not only in connexion with assisted immigration that this difficulty has arisen, but according to the High Commissioner it is being experienced, even by persons who are prepared to pay their own passages to Australia.
- I am very sorry to interrupt the continuity of the honorable member's remarks, but I must once more call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

- I rise to a point of order. I wish to know if, when drawing attention to the state of the Committee, an honorable member is in order in making any observations regarding the speech or conduct of another honorable member?
- An honorable member is not in order in so acting.
- I hope that the honorable member for Hunter will profit by your admonition. He has been most insulting to me. In his report the High Commissioner says -

quote.para: Unless some rapid increase in the means of transit occurs, a serious, perhaps disastrous, check to Australian immigration is bound to occur. The block in the case of emigrants, prepared to pay their own passage' money in full (in the steerage) is worse than in the ca'se of the assisted class.

speech.para: So that persons who are desirous of coming to Australia, and who are willing to pay their own passages -

talk.start.para: - I beg to draw attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

- I rise to order. I call attention to the fact that the proceedings of the Committee are being reduced to an absolute farce. You now perceive that the result of the ruling you gave the other night is to make it absolutely impossible for an honorable member to deliver a speech.
- That is not a point of order.
- It is a point of order.
- My ruling has been upheld by the Committee. The honorable member for Echuca will proceed.

- The High Commissioner, in his report, points out that it is unfortunate that at a. time when there is such an unusual demand for passages to Australia we should find ourselves in face of difficulties. There is no gainsaying the wisdom of the High Commissioner's remarks. What have the Government done to counteract the situation? I can only come to one conclusion, that the Ministry have net taken the necessary action to comply with Sir George Reid's request because of certain resolutions that have been carried by certain organizations, whose object is to make Australia a. close preserve for Australians, and to keep everybody else out. That is an unfortunate position. So far from having -a Government which recognises the responsibility of carrying out a wise policy, we have a Ministry in office that lends itself to those who favour a contrary course of action.
- I draw attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]
- The difficulties of the situation are certainly not light in view of these repeated interruptions. I am not seeking to waste the time of the Committee, but to bring forward facts.
- The honorable member's time is up.

. - 1 rise to a question of privilege. I submit that under the ruling given by yourself the other night the action of honorable members opposite in constantly calling for a quorum constitutes a breach of the privileges of honorable members.
- The honorable member must not discuss my ruling.

- I am not discussing your ruling. I am discussing the advantage that has been taken of it to reduce the proceedings of the Committee to an absolute nullity, and to prevent an Honorable member from making a speech of any kind whatever.
- Order 1
- This is a breach of the fundamental privilege of every honorable member to speak as a representative of the people.
- I rise to order.
- I have raised a question of privilege upon which there can be no point of order. A question of privilege must take precedence of all points of order.
- The Standing Orders specially make provision that a matter of privilege must be on motion. The honorable member for Parramatta has not submitted a motion.
- I intend to conclude with a motion.
- The motion must be submitted to the Chair when the question of privilege is raised.
- Not so.
- Unless a motion is submitted the Chairman cannot tell whether the matter is one of privilege or not.
- Under standing order 283 -

quote.para: Any member may rise to speak "to order " or upon a matter of privilege suddenly arising.

speech.para: Standing order 284 provides that -

quote.para: All questions of order and matters of privilege at any time arising shall, until decided, suspend the consideration and decision of every other question.

speech.para: The honorable member for Parramatta is in order.

talk.start.para: - An experienced ex-Chairman of Committees should have known that.
- There is another standing order which provides that a question of privilege must be raised on motion.
- I presume that the honorable member for Parramatta intends to conclude with a motion.

- I am not raising any question as to the validity of the ruling of the Chairman concerning the deduction from an honorable member's time of time occupied by calls for a quorum. I am taking the ruling to have been properly given. It has been confirmed by the Committee. But I am pointing out that the effect of it, as used by the honorable member for Hunter, is to reduce the proceedings of this Committee to a nullity. Indeed, it has reduced them to a screaming farce.
- I ask that the honorable member shall be compelled to withdraw that expression.
- The honorable member for Parramatta is not in order in describing the proceedings of the Committee as a farce.

- Then I withdraw the phrase. I submit that you have no right to permit the proceedings of the Committee to be rendered absolutely impossible under any ruling of yours as taken advantage of by the honorable member for Hunter. By this method of constantly calling for a quorum, and by honorable members opposite immediately leaving the chamber when a quorum has been formed, an honorable member can be prevented from speaking at all. An honorable member ought to be allowed to address the Committee in such a way as will enable him to make an intelligent, speech. But under these proceedings, which have been taken in accordance with a perfectly proper ruling of yours, the proceedings of the Committee render it impossible, not only for the making of a speech, but for the transaction of public business of any kind. I submit that any action which results in rendering the proceedings of the Committee devoid of result except for purposes of destructive mischief requires an immediate remedy. You are the custodian of the liberties of honorable members while you occupy the chair, and ought to be able to find some way out of this impasse. I cannot believe that what was done a few years ago in the New Zealand Parliament could have led to such results.
- The honorable member must not refer to my ruling.

- I am' not I am referring to a decision given in New Zealand seven years ago, to the effect that the time occupied by constituting a quorum should be deducted from the small amount of time allowed to honorable members under the Standing Orders.
- The honorable member must not discuss that question. He is now referring to my ruling.

- I am referring to what was in the public prints of New Zealand, and if incidentally that has a bearing upon your ruling, it ought not to debar me from referring to the subject. I am showing how the honorable member for Hunter is taking advantage of opportunities to reduce the proceedings of this Committee to a state of suspended animation as far as concerns the transaction of public business. The Government themselves should not tolerate the , Committee being reduced to an absolute nullity in this way by their own supporters, who obstruct business and prevent the Government from getting their work done. Some way ought to be found. I move -

quote.para: That the action of honorable members under a perfectly proper ruling of the Chairman of Committees on the question of forming quorums is a breach of the privileges of honorable members.

talk.start.para: .- I should like to direct attention to one or two considerations-
- I call attention to the state of the Committee, - [Quorum formed.]
- I move -

quote.para: That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: - I do not think that the motion of the honorable member for Bourke applies to questions of privilege.
- I have no alternative but to accept the motion.
- Is a motion affecting the free speech of honorable members - affecting the very right of speech - to be gagged ?
- According to the Standing Orders adopted on the 23rd November, 1905 -

quote.para: After any question has been proposed,* either in the House or in any Committee of the Whole, a motion may be made by any member, rising in his place, and without notice, and whether any other member is addressing the Chair or not, " That the question be now put," and the motion shall be put forthwith and decided without amendment or debate.

talk.start.para: - I submit that that standing order refers to ordinary business, and that a motion on"a question of privilege, is specifically excepted.
- If the honorable member disputes my ruling there is a proper procedure that he may take.
- A question of privilege supersedes all other business.

speech.para: Motion - That the question be now put - negatived.

talk.start.para: - My reasons for supporting the motion of the honorable member for Parramatta are to be found in the Constitution, and in the Standing Orders..
- Has the Chairman decided yet whether the motion is in order?

speech.para: The Chairman . - I have decided that such a motion is in order, but I think" that the motion is too indefinite to be accepted.

talk.start.para: - But you have accepted it, Mr. Poynton.
- I shall make it more definite, and I ask that it be accepted in the following form : -

quote.para: That the action of the honorable member for Hunter in repeatedly calling attention to the want of a quorum, under a perfectly proper ruling of the Chairman of Committees on the question of the forming of a quorum, is a breach of the privileges of honorable members.

talk.start.para: - I think that the names of the honorable member for Parramatta and the honorable member for Wentworth ought to be added to that of the honorable member for Hunter.

- If an honorable member has only half an hour in which to address himself to a certain question, and he is prevented from enjoying his right of free speech during the whole period by repeated calls for a quorum, honorable members having carefully left the Chamber to enable that to be done--
- I beg to call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed. ]

- The Federal Constitution, which embodies throughout the principles of democracy and representative government, declares, in section 49, that the " powers, privileges and immunities " of the members of the Senate and House of Representatives shall be such as are declared by Parliament, and, until declared, shall be those of the members of the House of Commons as at the establishment of the Commonwealth. Amongst the immunities, privileges, and powers of the members of the House of Commons at the time of Federation, was the absolute right of free speech, provided that it was exercised in accordance with the Standing Orders.
- I am afraid there is not a quorum present. [Quorum formed.]

- Chapter 21 of our Standing Orders provides for " rules of debate," and " the manner and right of speech." Now, the "right" of speech was denied to the honorable member for Echuca by an honorable member rising and calling repeatedly for a quorum in conjunction and conspiracy with other honorable members-
- Is the honorable member in order in saying that I am acting in conspiracy with other honorable members?
- I accept the honorable member's statement that that is not so. Mr. Charlton. - The honorable member has to accept the statement.
- That is true in a sense; for 1 am satisfied of some things, which the Standing Orders will not permit me to refer to, in connexion with the recent exhibition.
- I call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]

- Standing Orders from 253 to 262 lay down how an honorable member shall exercise the " right " of free speech in this Chamber ;. and the one outstanding feature is that he must be protected by the Chairman in addressing himself properly to any question which happens to be under discussion. If any honorable member wishes to stop another honorable member speaking, there is a straightforward, honest, open, manly way of doing so, by means of the closure standing order. Mr. Parker Moloney. - I call attention to the state of the Committee. [Quorum formed.]
- This is a 1,Ve organized farce !
- I ask that those words be withdrawn as unworthy and offensive. The honorable member has used the word " farce " repeatedly as descriptive of our proceedings.
- They are a farce, but he is responsible.
- I ask the honorable member for Parramatta to withdraw the remark that the proceedings! are a farce.
- I withdraw the observation, and substitute for the word " farce " the word " impasse."

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - On a point of order, Mr. Chairman, if it is out of order to apply the word "farce" to the proceedings of the Chamber, was the honorable member for South Sydney in order in saying as he entered the chamber just now, " This is a comedy."
- I have no precedent to go upon, but the word " comedy " means something very different from " farce."

- The honorable member for Indi interjected during the remarks of the honorable member for Brisbane, " Yes, it is a farce, and it is due to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition." I require that remark to be withdrawn.
- I withdraw the word " farce " and shall describe the situation as an " impasse." for which the Opposition is responsible.

speech.para: Ml- KELLY. - Now that honorable members have had their little fun, let us get to business.

talk.start.para: - If the honorable member is coming to his point, I think we had better have a quorum.
- There is a quorum present.

- The action taken by the honorable member for Hunter was undoubtedly designed to prevent the honorable member for Echuca from addressing the Chamber. As soon as he had uttered half a sentence the honorable member would call attention to the want of a quorum, and the honorable member for Echuca had to remain silent while a band of members of the Ministerial party walked in, in single file, and passed out through another doorway. The effect of this action was to closure the honorable member. It is not necessary for any honorable member who wishes to maintain any reputation for manliness in the conduct of public business to proceed to closure an honorable member by this roundabout method. Under the closure resolutions an honorable member may at any time move, ' ' That the question be now put," or that an honorable member be no longer heard, and such motion must be put and decided without further debate.
- I call attention to the want of a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

- I have a statement to make. Having considered the motion submitted by the honorable member for Parramatta, i have come to the conclusion that it is not in order, inasmuch as anything which it is permissible for an honorable member to do under the Standing Orders cannot be treated as a breach of privilege. The honorable member for Hunter had a right, just as any other honorable member has, under the Standing Orders, to draw attention to the want of a quorum. I therefore rule the motion out of order.
- Do I understand, sir-
- The honorable member must not discuss my ruling. There is only one course open to him, and with that he himself is familiar.

- I desire to make a personal explanation. The motion you have just ruled out of order, Mr. Chairman, referred particularly to myself, and I wish to say that the statements made during the debate upon it by the honorable member for Parramatta and others, that an arrangement had been made for me to call attention to the want of a quorum, and for a procession of members to then file into the chamber, is absolutely incorrect. I had no word with any honorable member as to the attitude that I adopted. The honorable member for Bourke came to me and requested me not to do what I did; but I replied that I claimed my right, as a member of the Committee to call attention to the want of a quorum just as the honorable member for Parramatta and the honorable member for Wentworth have done on numerous occasions.

- By way of personal explanation, I desire to say that I have never availed myself of the power given by the Standing Orders to call attention to the want of a quorum with the object of preventing any honorable member speaking. I have used it to secure an audience for a member; but I have never abused it.
. - I move -

speech.para: That the Committee dissents from the Chairman's ruling to the effect that the motion of privilege moved by the honorable member for Parramatta is not in order.

talk.start.para: - Will the honorable member resume his seat ? A remark has just been made by the Minister of External Affairs that I cannot pass over. On my stating the motion to the Committee, the Minister said to me, " And you accept that?" I distinctly resent any instructions, either from a Minister or any other honorable member.

- I submit, Mr. Chairman, that your ruling is wrong, inasmuch as the effect of it would be to Bring about a complete paralysis of the opportunities presented to honorable members for carrying out the fundamental purpose for which, thry are here as . representatives of the people. You ruled on a previous occasion that the time occupied in calling for a quorum, and in the exercise of other rights possessed by honorable members, and which also take up a considerable time, must be deducted from the time allotted to each honorable member under the Standing Orders. That is an entirely arbitrary ruling in this sense-
-The honorable member must not in any way question my ruling.
- He is always reflecting on the Chair.
- I ask that that remark be withdrawn.
- I ask the honorable member to withdraw the remark.
- I withdraw.
- I had no intention of reflecting on any ruling, but I submit that for any honorable member to take advantage of a ruling by yourself,

- a perfectly proper ruling - and so to use it as to prevent an honorable .member from delivering an address, is to commit a complete breach of the privileges of Parliament. The very purpose for which this Committee is constituted is that honorable members may be afforded an opportunity to express their opinions fully and freely for half-an-hour at a time upon any question which may come before it for its decision. I submit that your ruling, sir, must be so interpreted as to provide for proper and reasonable debate. When you gave that ruling, you had in your mind the proper conduct of the business of the Committee. You must, therefore, recognise that any action taken by the honorable member for Hunter under that ruling which prevents the business of this Committee from being transacted must, in its very essence, be a breach of the privileges of Parliament. This is not merely a question of preventing an honorable member from speaking, although that in itself is bad enough. Such action as that of the honorable member for Hunter must bring the transaction of business to a standstill. That is the aspect of it which I challenge as being a breach of the privileges of Parliament. I submit that no action taken by any honorable member ought to result in bringing about a complete paralysis of the functions of this Committee. By the simple method of calling attention to the absence of a quorum, and by reason of honorable members opposite acting in concert with him - I will not say by arrangement, but acting concurrently, even if independently of him - the honorable member for Hunter has brought about a complete abrogation of the privileges of Parliament, which in their very nature must guarantee the right of free discussion to honorable members, and the right of the Committee to transact the business which is before it. I take this fundamental objection to the action of the honorable member. I say that anything which prevents the business of Parliament from proceeding in an orderly way is a breach of parliamentary privilege.
- It is a public scandal.

- All this livelong day honorable members opposite have been preventing the business of Parliament from proceeding. That is only too apparent. I say that our Standing Orders must be so interpreted as to permit of the business of Parliament being transacted, no matter how much it may involve the curtailment of the rights of individuals. You, sir, may curtail the privileges of honorable members, but you must not prevent Parliament from discharging the very function for which it was created. This motion is intended to defeat action which amounts to an abrogation of the functions of Parliament, which tends to bring that institution into contempt, and to convert its proceedings into a farce.
- The honorable member is the chief clown of his party.
- I call attention to the insulting remark of the honorable member for Hunter.
- I ask the honorable member for Parramatta what insulting re-, mark I made?
- I understood the honorable member to say that I was ' ' the chief clown of my party."
- I ask that the honorable member be called upon to withdraw that statement.

- Order ! I understand the honorable member to say that he did not make the remark which has been attributed to him, and in the circumstances I ask the honorable member for Parramatta to withdraw his accusation.
- Does the honorable member say that he did not make that statement ?
- I ask the honorable member for Hunter whether he made the statement which the. honorable member for Parramatta has attributed to him?
- I say emphatically that I did not.
- In view of the assurance which the honorable member has given me, I ask the honorable member for Parramatta to withdraw the accusation, which he made.
- I withdraw it. I must have misheard.
- But the statement was made nevertheless, and the honorable member who made it ought to own up to it. It would be a manly thing to do.
- I have stated my position, and I shall- leave the motion at. that. Under your ruling, sir, this Committee owing to what the honorable member for Hunter has been doing all themorning
- And the honorable member for Parramatta all the night.
