- This is one of those questions which are not affected by. rules of logic, and it does not follow that, because the Committee is properly constituted, the rule in that connexion may not be pushed to the absurdity of destroying the usefulness of the Committee. That is the distinction.
-- The honorable member must not discuss that matter.

- I am replying to an interjection to the effect that because 1 endeavoured to keep a quorum during the night my action was on all -fours with that of the honorable member for Hunter, who persistently and of set purpose has prevented business from being carried on.

.- I submit that the position taken up by the honorable member for Parramatta is an untenable one. The Standing Orders provide that in the event of the Committee not being properly constituted any honorable member has a right to ca.ll attention to the absence qf a. quorum.. I have merely exercised my right in that direction, as a representative of the people. When the honorable member says that 1 did so for the purpose of preventing the transaction of public business, I say that his statement is incorrect. I merely followed the example which he himself set on numerous occasions during the past forty-eight hours, even when he himself was in possession of the Chair. But immediately I exercised my right, the honorable member desires to make capital out of it. This is the first Commonwealth Parliament of which I have teen a member, and I have no recollection of having previously called attention to the absence of a quorum'. I did so merely to insure that the Committee should be properly constituted, and that honorable members should hear what the honorable member for Echuca had to say. I have taken no part whatever in the discussion that has been proceeding during the past two days, and which, in my judgment, has served no useful purpose. Honorable members opposite are just as much bound to keep a quorum as I am.

. - I think that the honorable member for Parramatta, has gone to the very root of this question by appealing to honorable members to consider the relationship which exists between this Chamber and its Standing Orders. Standing Orders are designed to expedite the transaction of public business. That is the primary reason for their existence. They are also intended to protect the rights and privileges of honorable members. Every honorable member will agree that I have not mis-stated the chief functions which are discharged by Standing Orders. Under a standing order which was recently adopted, a ruling has been given by you, sir. which has resulted in powers being given to individual members which they did not previously possess. The limitation of debate has been the subject of very much heart-burning, not only in this Parliament, but in other Parliaments. It has been found necessary that there should be some limitation imposed, and we were guided by the experience of other Parliaments when we adopted such a limitation in 1906. These limitations have had superimposed upon them certain safeguards which have been found absolutely necessary as the result of experience. The right of free speech in this chamber is surely an important one. It is the very purpose for which Parliament has been constituted and summoned. The very word "Parliament" conveys that.
- The honorable member ought to recollect that when his party were in power the House was " gagged " regularly.
- That remark does not become the honorable member.
- Is it not true?
- No, it is not. I was associated with no party at that time.
- Then I will say the party with which the honorable member is now associated.

- That entirely alters the position, as the Honorary Minister, with his agile mind, will recognise. The adoption of a standing order imposing a time limit upon speeches has always been accompanied by certain precautions. The precaution accompanying the use of the closure is that at least twenty-four members must vote in favour of its application before it can be applied. What does the honorable member for Hunter desire? He desires to have reposed in him alone the power of preventing any honorable member from making a speech. That is one of the gravest breaches of privilege of which we can possibly conceive. It is one of the gravest abuses of privilege of which an honorable member can be guilty. The fact is that the honorable member for Echuca was prevented by an important public engagement from addressing himself to a matter which was before the Committee yesterday, and which was before it again to-day. He came here this morning prepared to make his speech, and was prevented from doing so under the Standing Orders.
- Keep to the point.

- That is the point, and that is why honorable members opposite do not like it. They know that unless, an injury has been done to some honorable member there is no breach of privilege involved. I am pointing out that an injury has been done to the honorable member for Echuca. The Standing Orders were devised for the protection of the privileges of honorable members. As soon as any honorable member makes use of those Standing Orders to prevent free speech in this chamber, unless he makes use of them in the way that has been provided-
- That is exactly what I did.
- The honorable member for Laanecoorie was not present this morning.

- I was present the whole time. I was one of those who assisted to make a quorum when the honorable member for Hunter so persistently called attention to the lack of a quorum. Did the honorable member realize what he was doing?
- Oh, yes.
- Then he stands self-confessed as an honorable member who has deprived another honorable member of the rights which he has under the Standing Orders.
- Order !

- It has been urged that a breach of the privileges of the honorable member for Echuca, as well as of other honorable members, has been committed. The matter -has been submitted to you, sir, for your consideration. You have given a certain ruling, and I am now advancing reasons why we should disagree with that ruling. Now that the matter has been taken from the immediate personal control of the Chairman, I submit, with respect, that honorable members who have to give a decision on this matter ought to weigh carefully the manner in which they shall vote. If they feel that it is not a breach of privilege for an honorable member to be prevented from making his speech in the way provided for in the Standing Orders, they should vote accordingly. If", however, they feel that a. breach of privilege has been committed, I trust that they will not hesitate to vote for the motion proposed by the honorable member for Parramatta. Honorable members were warned at the time when the previous motion for disagreement with the Chairman's ruling was under consideration, that the very thing that has happened would occur. They denied that it was possible. New they are causing the evil to happen, I regret to say.
- It started on the honorable member's own side.
- I do not care where it started. It was wrong, and the honorable member will not find me countenancing anything of the sort.
- The honorable member is doing so now.

- I am sorry that the honorable member misunderstands what I am saying. I ask honorable members to view this matter as one which affects the rights and privileges of every individual member. It should not be viewed from a personal stand-point, but from a consideration of its probable effect on parliamentary life and on our proceedings. There are some honorable members who have a profound contempt for anything that is old.
- Does not the honorable member think that he is wasting time?

- It is an extraordinary thing that immediately one comes to the part of an argument which may have some weight and force, an honorable member like the honorable member for South Sydney comes out with some banal and unintelligible interjection which has nothing to do with the subject. Honorable members should consider the effect of what is now happening upon the future proceedings of the Commonwealth Parliament, and possibly of other deliberative assemblies. They ought to be imbued with a proper sense of responsibility. The rights of individual members should be preserved, and the privilege of expressing our views in the councils of the nation should not be frittered away.

.-This Committee has now sat for about 50 hours, and during that period the members of the Opposition have had every opportunity of saying whatever they wished to say on the subjects brought before us. They were given the most untrammelled freedom. No restriction was placed upon their right of expressing their opinions. They availed themselves of all the opportunities afforded by the Standing Orders, in order, if possible, to delay the proceedings of the Committee. Last night, time after time, they frequently caused the bells to be rung to call attention to the absence of a quorum. I admit that they did so in accordance with their rights under the Standing Orders. But they were not compelled to do so, however, in order that they might secure opportunities of expressing their opinions. Those opportunities were not in question. When you, Mr. Chairman, had given a ruling on any particular, question, the members of the Opposition immediately availed themselves of a fresh opportunity to express dissent, in order to create further delay.

- I rise to order. The honorable member for Bourke has just stated that honorable members on this side have dissented from your rulings during the course of this long sitting for no other reason than to delay and obstruct public business. I submit that the reasons that I gave to you on a previous occasion for dissenting from ypur ruling-
- The honorable member must not, under cover of a point of order, make a speech.
- I ask that the offensive and inaccurate statement of the honorable member for Bourke shall be withdrawn, and I hope that he will not further transgress.
- The honorable member for Bourke was not in order in making such an imputation.

- I am very sorry, because I had not the slightest desire to hurt the tender susceptibilities of the honorable member who has raised the point. I am called upon by the Chairman to recall the iwds 1 used, and I do so in accordance ww< instructions. I should like to point out that the great majority of honorable members opposite availed themselves of the opportunities afforded by the Standing Orders to call attention to the state of the Committee. Now, because an honorable member on this side, in the exercise of his rights, has done the same, the honorable member for Parramatta has moved a motion dissenting from the ruling of the Chairman. The outstanding fact of these proceedings is that if there has been a breach of privilege it was committed by the majority of honorable members on the Opposition side ; and that when an honorable member on this side exercised the same right as they have done, and the Chairman ruled that there was no breach of privilege, the Opposition at once express dissent from the ruling. I again put it to you, Mr. Chairman, that it is perfectly within your power, as the presiding officer, to determine what is a frivolous motion or point of order, and to decline to allow such a thing to be entertained. If ever there was a frivolous motion submitted for the consideration of a Chairman of Committees it is this one. It has already been decided that it is within the privileges of an honorable member to call for a quorum, and yet honorable members opposite now object because the Chairman has' given a ruling in accordance with practice. 'Is not that an outrage on parliamentary practice? Is it not abuse ? I call upon the Chairman to exercise his rights in accordance with common, sense and sound judgment, and to rule the motion out of order, on the ground that it is frivolous.

.- What has happened this morning furnishes another proof that the practice and privilege of Parliament is a two-edged sword that can be used by both parties. What surprises me is that men who know what parliamentary life is, and what the game of politics is, whether they sit behind a Go.vernment or in Opposition, should express amazement when a weapon which they themselves have been using is at length used against themselves, and when that with which they have been hitting other people is used for hitting them'. I can quite understand honorable members talking like this to people outside, but I do not understand their doing so in this chamber. I have seen this sort of thing many times during my short parliamentary career of six years, and other honorable members have seen it often during their lives. When an Opposition sets out to obstruct the business of a Government, the majority of Government supporters leave the chamber. lt is rather a good thing that they do, because what is said by the other side is generally of a nature to provoke scenes. Then the Opposition sets to work to call for a quorum, in order to bring the Ministerial supporters back into the chamber, and compel them to listen. All these calls for quorums, of course, interfere with the member who is speaking. But every one knows why it is done. When a call is made, the bells ring for two minutes, and if the necessary number of honorable members doi not appear, a quorum is not formed, and? the business lapses altogether. I have made a remark about people complaining as to things which they have done themselves.. Let us consider what has happened in this case.I take it that the trouble started at about midnight on. Wednesday. 1 have always understood, until quite recently - and was told shortly after I became a member of this Parliament - that the half-hour between midnight and half-past 12 is " taboo " as far as concerns calls for quorums. That idea was impressed upon me very strongly ; and I can remember, on an occasion when one honorable member rather injudiciously called for a quorum during that time, hearing him severely taken to task by members of his own party, and told that when honorable members left the chamber to go to supper, it was recognised as a piece of good taste that attention should not be called to the absence of a quorum. Now, what happened on Wednesday night ? The first call for a quorum was made at thirteen minutes past 12, the next was at seventeen past 12, the next at twenty past 12, and the next at fifty-five past. There was another call at ten minutes past 1 - and that, by the way, was made by a gentleman from whom we should not have expected such conduct. There was another call at 1.16. That was the beginning of the trouble. Now, what has happened in the case of the honorable member for Echuca ? When he was speaking this morning a call for a quorum was made at 11.33. At11.35 two minutes later, the honorable member for Wentworth again interrupted by calling for a quorum. At n.36 there was another call. At 11. 41 the honorable member for Parramatta again interrupted the speaker. In the space of eight minutes there were four calls for a quorum, and those were made by honorable members who now profess to be indignant that the honorable member for Echuca was prevented from making his speech without interruption.
- Continue the record; be fair.

- The reason for these calls for a quorum was perfectly understood amongst ourselves. It was all part of the game. We know what the game is. The honorable members who made these calls did not care about interrupting the honorable member for Echuca at all. All they wanted to do was to compel Ministerial supporters to come into the chamber, just as honorable members on the Ministerial side used to do when the Fusion Government were in office. After these four calls for quorums in eight minutes, the honorable member for Hunter apparently thought that the game might as well be persevered in.
- I think there were two more calls from the honorable member for Wentworth and the honorable member for Parramatta before the honorable member for Hunter intervened.
- The next call, at ii.42, was made by the honorable member for Hunter, and then he started to keep it up.
- How many times did the honorable member for Hunter call ?
- He called continually. The honorable member for Hunter, in so doing, exercised precisely the same right as the honorable member for Wentworth and the honorable member for Parramatta had done.
- My calls for a quorum were to get an audience for the honorable member for Echuca.

- Why should not the honorable member for Hunter be credited with the same desire? Why should there be this outcry about interference with the privileges of honorable members when we know perfectly well who started the game, and what the object of it was ? Is it not rather childish? We have seen the same sort of thing before in this House. If the ruling of the Chairman is wrong, I want to know what rule is to be laid down in regard to calls for a quorum? Is the Chairman to take it upon himself to say that when honorable members on the Opposition side call for a quorum four times in eight minutes they are doing right, and that when an honorable member on the Ministerial side does the same thing he is doing wrong? I cannot help saying that the whole position to-day has resolved itself into a farce. As I said at the beginning, the practice of Parliament is a two-edged sword. Its use can be abused to defeat completely the ends originally intended. I do really think that honorable members might stop this silly business. I am afraid that that word is unparliamentary, but it is awfully difficult, in a debate like this, to express oneself without falling foul of the Chair. I do think, however, that when we are talking to each other, we might recognise the fact that honorable members on both sides are not fools. Just as we can see through the Opposition, the Opposition can see through us; and what is the use of continuing this nonsense ?

.- The honorable member for Gippsland has quoted just about half the facts; and he is quite satisfied so long as they are cheered by the party of which he always professes to be independent. A change has taken place during this sitting, the merits of which I shall not discuss, with regard to the right of speech in this chamber some thirty-nine hours ago. I moved dissent from the ruling of the Chairman, on the ground that just such a means as has been adopted by the honorable member for Hunter would be adopted to prevent honorable members from being heard, if there was such a desire. My main point is that, when a quorum is called, the time occupied should not be counted against the honorable member then addressing the Chamber; and if that point is not upheld, abuse must, as has been proved, creep in. There is a difference between obtaining an audience for an honorable member and preventing him speaking at all. The records show that the honorable member for Hunter called for a quorum at 11.53, 11.54, 12.1, n2-3, 12.8, 12.10, and 12.1.5 o'clock, at which time the hon'orable member for Echuca had to resume his seat, without being able to complete a single sentence. It is quite true, as the honorable member for Gippsland says, that we can see through each other, and know each other's sincerities and insincerities; and we quite realize the difference I have pointed out between keeping an audience and endeavouring to prevent an honorable member speaking. I took the first opportunity to protest, and I shall always protest, against any further abuse of our privileges in this regard. If honorable members opposite desire to prevent discussion, there is a more straightforward and decent course open to them by the application of the closure standing order ; and they ought to act like men, and not merely as tricksters of the Standing Orders.
- I ask that the word ' tricksters ' ' be withdrawn.
- I used the word in all sincerity, but, if it is objected to, I, of course, withdraw it.

speech.para: Motion negatived.

talk.start.para: . - I know there are varying opinions as to the necessity for a larger population by means of immigration, but we are all at one as to the urgent necessity for defence, which, of course, can be provided only by our own people. We have no desire, as I said previously, to take advantage of the necessities of those who may be prepared to act as mercenaries ; and in times of peace we ought to secure a sufficient number of properly trained men to insure our protection. A great deal has been done, and is being done, in this regard ; but any one who has considered the undefended condition of this great continent and its marvellous wealth, must be struck with the almost criminal inaction that has been exhibited. The Governments have relegated immigration proposals to the pigeon-hole, and our puny efforts have been compared with the highly successful efforts of Canada to introduce energetic and enterprising immigrants. It is hardly fair, however, to compare Australia with Canada, because, unlike Australia, the Dominion is only some six or seven days' steam from, the great centres of population. This gives Canada a tremendous advantage ; and those immigrants who have gone there have really proved to be immigration agents on their own account, and have been the means of inducing numbers of their friends to follow them. In this way the very cream of the available population has gone from the Old Country and the Continent to the Dominion. Be' that as it may, Australia has not availed herself of the great advantages; she possesses. In Canada, when a man sows his wheat crop, it is covered for four months with snow ; and during the winter the cattle have to be housed and hand-fed. These two facts alone show that Australia,, though far distant, possesses great advantages, which have only to be made known to attract the very best class of people.
- Do people not know those facts already?
- No; and this is realized by the Government, who are taking steps to furnish information to the people in Great Britain and on the Continent much more extensively than in the past.
- Is not that satisfactory ?

- Entirely, sofar as it goes ; but is the honorable member, who is an ardent supporter of immigration, satisfied with the results 7 The Prime Minister of the previous Liberal Government made certain overtures to the>

speech.para: States at the Hobart Conference, but his proposals were simply "turned down." I hope that at no distant date this, or some other Government, will realize the importance of this question, and secure for Australia a steady stream of people, who will not only become producers, but will form no inconsiderable part of our line of defence.
Proposed vote agreed to.

Division 33 (Papua), £53,000 ; division 34 (Northern Territory), £274,385 ; division 35 (Port Augusta Railway). £104,410; division 36 (Mail Service to the Pacific Islands). £19,850 ; and division 37 (Miscellaneous), £40,005, agreed to.
Defence.
Divisions 38 to 62 (Administrative and Naval), £908,520, postponed.
Divisions 63 to .83 (Military Forces), £1,603,880, agreed to.
Trade and Customs.

talk.start.para: . - I am sorry to reduce for a moment the speed with which the legislative machine is now travelling, but I desire to refer to a promise which I made a few weeks ago to the honorable member for Maranoa in regard to the question of the percentage of moisture in butter for export, which has engaged the attention of the Parliament from time to time. I promised the honorable member that, since there was not likely to be an opportunity for the House to deal with a motion bearing on the question, I would give him an opportunity on the Estimates of my Department to discuss the question, and test the feeling of the Committee. He then assured me that there was a majority of members of the House in favour of the maximum moisture contents permissible being increased from 15 per cent, to 16 per cent., and I propose now to give him an opportunity to test the question. I, personally, shall regret very much the affirmation of such an increase by honorable members, but I am willing 'to leave the whole question to the decision of the Committee.
- We will agree to the increase.
- Will the honorable member give me his assurance that it is a fact that there is a majority of honorable members in favour of the proposal ?
- I can give the honorable member that assurance.
- Very well, we will agree to the alteration.

speech.para: Divisions 84 to 96 (Department of Trade and Customs). £395,445, agreed to.
Progress reported.

subdebateinfo.title: Order of Business - Revision of Standing Orders

talk.start.para: . - In moving -

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn,

speech.para: I desire to state that on Tuesday next the consideration of the Referenda Bills will take precedence of all other business, and will constitute the business for the rest of the week. After the Attorney-General has moved the second reading of these Bills, the debate will be adjourned until Wednesday, when it will be resumed by- the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: .- I suggest that you, Mr. Speaker, as Chairman of the Standing Orders Committee, should invite that Committee to give consideration to certain questions brought forward today, as to the propriety of allowing attention to be called to the state of the House so frequently as to render argument impossible. I suggest that a standing order might be framed to meet that difficulty, but am not touching the question in any partisan spirit. It is equally essential to all Governments that the business of the House should be so conducted at -all times that argument may not be rendered impossible.
- Like most Standing Orders, they require to be amended from time to time.
- Quite so.
- Shall we have an opportunity to discuss such an amendment of the Standing Orders as is suggested before it is brought into force?

- Anything that the Standing Orders Committee may do would come to naught without the sanction of the House. I presume that the desire of the Leader of the Opposition is that the Standing Orders Committee shall take into consideration the too frequent use of the standing order in relation to the absence of a quorum, with the object of preventing an honorable member from speaking. I presume that he also suggests that we take action to prevent the standing order being so used as to obstruct business.

speech.para: Mr. GROOM (Darling Downs) [3.44I. - I should like to ask the Prime Minister what business will be taken after the Referenda Bills' have been introduced on Tuesday.

talk.start.para: - I am afraid that the Attorney-General will find it necessary to occupy most of our time on Tuesday, but, should time permit, some small measures may be proceeded with.
- Not the Estimates?
- No.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
